title.value: Can Workers Meaningfully Consent to Workplace Wellbeing Technologies?
title.justification: The title of the paper as provided by the user and confirmed in the document.
title.quote: Can Workers Meaningfully Consent to Workplace Wellbeing Technologies?

extractions.description: The paper explores the challenges workers face when consenting to workplace wellbeing technologies, using a focus group study to reveal their concerns and expectations. It suggests interventions to support meaningful consent, drawing on critical computing and feminist scholarship to frame consent as a structural condition rather than an individual choice.

type.justification: The study involves collecting data from six multi-stakeholder focus groups involving 15 participants to understand their perspectives on consent to workplace wellbeing technologies.
type.quote: Using a hypothetical case to prompt reflection among six multi-stakeholder focus groups involving 15 participants, we explored participants’ expectations and capacity to consent to these technologies.

name.justification: The paper investigates human interactions and ethical considerations related to workplace wellbeing technologies, fitting within the scope of Human-Centered Computing.
name.quote: CCS CONCEPTS • Human-centered computing → Empirical studies in collaborative and social computing.

name.justification: The paper discusses ethical issues related to privacy and consent in the use of AI-driven workplace technologies.
name.quote: However, given the inherent and structural power dynamics in the workplace, the prevalent approach of accepting tacit compliance to monitor work activities rather than seeking workers’ meaningful consent raises privacy and ethical concerns.

name.justification: The paper addresses privacy concerns and data governance related to AI technologies used for workplace wellbeing monitoring.
name.quote: Privacy research has however demonstrated that such consent practices may not meaningfully model consent [8, 98], and are ill-suited for sensing technologies designed to unobtrusively collect large quantities of individual and contextual data.
